full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Sarah. How are you feeling today?
Client: Hi Dr. Thompson. I'm... I'm okay, I guess. A bit nervous about today's session.
Therapist: That's understandable. We're here to support you.
Client: Thanks. I've been thinking a lot about what we discussed last time, about my childhood and how it might relate to my experience in the military. It's been... difficult to process.
Therapist: You're very brave for facing this. Shall we begin?
Client: Yes, I think I'm ready. Where should I start?
Therapist: Let's focus on a specific memory. Take your time.

Client: Okay... I'm thinking about a night when I was seven. My dad had been drinking, and he came into my room... (voice trembles) He was angry about something, I don't remember what. But I remember feeling so small and scared.
Therapist: You're doing great. Keep going.

Client: (takes a deep breath) He started yelling, his face was so close to mine. I could smell the alcohol on his breath. I wanted to disappear, to sink into my bed and vanish. My heart was racing so fast, I thought it might burst out of my chest.
Therapist: Stay with that feeling. You're safe here.
Client: (voice shaking) I... I can't. It's too much.
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You can handle this.
Client: (inhales deeply) Okay... I remember pulling my blanket up, trying to hide. But he grabbed it and threw it off. I was shaking so hard, and I started to cry. That made him even angrier.
Therapist: You're being very brave. Continue when you're ready.
Client: He... he grabbed my arm. It hurt so much. I can still feel his fingers digging into my skin. (starts crying) I'm sorry, I...
Therapist: It's okay to feel emotional. You're doing well.
Client: (wiping tears) Thank you. It's just... this memory, it's so vivid. I can hear his voice, smell the alcohol, feel the pain in my arm. It's like I'm there again.
Therapist: Remember, you're here now. You're safe.
Client: Right, I'm here. I'm safe. (takes another deep breath) After he grabbed my arm, he started shaking me. I was so terrified, I couldn't even scream. I just froze.
Therapist: You're handling this incredibly well. Keep going.

Client: I remember wishing my mom would come in, save me. But she never did. I felt so alone, so helpless. It's the same feeling I had during my first combat mission. That overwhelming fear, the feeling of being trapped.
Therapist: I hear you. You're making important connections.
Client: Yeah, I... I never realized how similar those feelings were until now. In both situations, I felt like I had no control, like I was at the mercy of forces much bigger than me.
Therapist: That's a powerful insight. How do you feel now?
Client: Exhausted, but... also a bit relieved? Like I've let go of something I've been holding onto for a long time.
Therapist: That's often how it feels. You've done excellent work today.
Client: Thank you, Dr. Thompson. I never thought I'd be able to talk about this without completely falling apart.
Therapist: You've shown tremendous strength. How about we wrap up?
Client: Yes, I think that would be good. I feel drained, but in a way, I also feel lighter. Is that normal?
Therapist: It's very common. You've processed difficult emotions.
Client: I see. Well, thank you again. I know we still have a lot to work through, but I feel like I've made some progress today.
Therapist: You absolutely have. We'll continue next week. Take care, Sarah.
Client: Thank you, Dr. Thompson. See you next week.
